A **kobold lord**, k, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It has the strongest weapon attack among [kobolds](/wiki/Kobold_\(monster_class\) "Kobold (monster class)"), and possesses [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance").

A kobold lord [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") is [poisonous](/wiki/Poison "Poison") to eat.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Kobold lords are now known as **kobold leaders**, with "lord" and "lady" being gendered titles.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Origin](#Origin)

- [5 Variants](#Variants)

  - [5.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [5.2 GruntHack](#GruntHack)
  - [5.3 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [5.4 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [5.5 xNetHack](#xNetHack)
  - [5.6 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [5.7 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [6 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [7 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly-generated kobold lords are always hostile. A [large kobold](/wiki/Large_kobold "Large kobold") can [grow up](/wiki/Grow_up "Grow up") into a kobold lord.

Kobold lords may appear among the hostile kobolds that generate in [throne rooms](/wiki/Throne_room "Throne room"), as well as the various monsters that can be randomly generated by [looting](/wiki/Looting "Looting") a throne while [confused](/wiki/Confused "Confused") and carrying gold (provided there is no [chest](/wiki/Chest "Chest") on the level).

A kobold lord has a 1⁄4 chance of [generating with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") a stack of [darts](/wiki/Dart "Dart").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

## Strategy

Though they are the strongest type of kobold a character will encounter, kobold lords are still not especially strong overall, but the strength of their weapon attack's dice means that they can pose trouble for careless early game characters with their darts or a found weapon, especially ones that have not yet found a viable set of armor.

## History

The kobold lord first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Kobold (Dungeons & Dragons)](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kobold_\(Dungeons_%26_Dragons\) "wikipedia:Kobold (Dungeons & Dragons)")***

Kobolds are creatures that appear in many fantasy-themed works and media, which often borrow significantly from Germanic folklore - Germanic kobolds are a form of sprite that are generally benevolent if treated with kindness, but will respond to disrespect with anything ranging from pranks to even outright attacking and killing offenders.

*[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")* in particular - and by extension, *NetHack* and many of its variants - depicts the kobold as a race of small reptilian humanoids with long tails, distantly related to dragons; earlier editions gave kobolds more dog-like features, which lead to many depictions of kobolds in Japanese media leaning harder in that direction after the popularity of the anime franchise *Record of Lodoss War*. Fantasy kobolds are often considered weak "cannon fodder" monsters that can be cunning and strong in groups, similar to goblins.

## Variants

Some variants make adjustments so that female counterparts to the kobold lord are properly named and generated.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), two kobold lords are generated alongside [Kroo the Kobold King](/wiki/Kroo_the_Kobold_King "Kroo the Kobold King") in the room-and-corridors variant of the [kobold level](/wiki/Kobold_level "Kobold level") at level creation.

### GruntHack

In [GruntHack](/wiki/GruntHack "GruntHack"), kobold lords are replaced by [racial monster](/wiki/Racial_monster "Racial monster") [lords and ladies](/wiki/Lord_\(GruntHack\) "Lord (GruntHack)"), which kobolds are eligible to generate as.

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), kobold lords and other kobolds have a mutual [grudge](/wiki/Grudge "Grudge") with [elves](/wiki/Elf_\(monster_attribute\) "Elf (monster attribute)").

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), kobold lords are lawful, and become an invalid form for [polymorph](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph").

A kobold lord may appear as the ruler of a randomly-generated [throne room](/wiki/Throne_room#dNetHack "Throne room") - his court can contain [kobold shamans](/wiki/Kobold_shaman "Kobold shaman"), [large kobolds](/wiki/Large_kobold "Large kobold"), [kobolds](/wiki/Kobold "Kobold"), [lemures](/wiki/Lemures "Lemures"), and [imps](/wiki/Imp "Imp").

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), the monster is known as a **kobold leader**, with females referred to as kobold ladies.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), the monster is referred to as a **kobold noble**, with females referred to as kobold ladies.

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), the monster is also known as a kobold noble as in EvilHack.

## Encyclopedia entry

The race of kobolds are reputed to be an artificial creation  
of a master wizard (demi-god?). They are about 3' tall with  
a vaguely dog-like face. They bear a violent dislike of the  
Elven race, and will go out of their way to cause trouble  
for Elves at any time.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 456](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L456)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")

Kobold lord

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
k kobold lord
Difficulty 3
Attacks Weapon 2d4
k kobold lord
Difficulty 3
Attacks

Weapon 2d4

Base level 2
Base experience 22
Speed 6
Base AC 10
Base MR 0
Alignment -4 (chaotic)
Frequency (by normal means) 1 (Very rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 500
Nutritional value 200
Size Small
Resistances Poison
Resistances conveyed None

A kobold lord:

  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • is poisonous to eat.
  • is omnivorous.
  • is a lord to its kind.
  • is male.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • can pick up weapons and food.
  • has infravision.
  • can be seen through infravision.
Reference monst.c#line583

A kobold lord, k, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. It has the strongest weapon attack among kobolds, and possesses poison resistance.

A kobold lord corpse is poisonous to eat.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

Kobold lords are now known as kobold leaders, with "lord" and "lady" being gendered titles.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Origin
  • 5 Variants
    • 5.1 SLASH'EM
    • 5.2 GruntHack
    • 5.3 UnNetHack
    • 5.4 dNetHack
    • 5.5 xNetHack
    • 5.6 EvilHack
    • 5.7 Hack'EM
  • 6 Encyclopedia entry
  • 7 References

Generation

Randomly-generated kobold lords are always hostile. A large kobold can grow up into a kobold lord.

Kobold lords may appear among the hostile kobolds that generate in throne rooms, as well as the various monsters that can be randomly generated by looting a throne while confused and carrying gold (provided there is no chest on the level).

A kobold lord has a 1⁄4 chance of generating with a stack of darts.[1]

Strategy

Though they are the strongest type of kobold a character will encounter, kobold lords are still not especially strong overall, but the strength of their weapon attack's dice means that they can pose trouble for careless early game characters with their darts or a found weapon, especially ones that have not yet found a viable set of armor.

History

The kobold lord first appears in NetHack 3.0.0.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Kobold (Dungeons & Dragons)

Kobolds are creatures that appear in many fantasy-themed works and media, which often borrow significantly from Germanic folklore - Germanic kobolds are a form of sprite that are generally benevolent if treated with kindness, but will respond to disrespect with anything ranging from pranks to even outright attacking and killing offenders.

Dungeons & Dragons in particular - and by extension, NetHack and many of its variants - depicts the kobold as a race of small reptilian humanoids with long tails, distantly related to dragons; earlier editions gave kobolds more dog-like features, which lead to many depictions of kobolds in Japanese media leaning harder in that direction after the popularity of the anime franchise Record of Lodoss War. Fantasy kobolds are often considered weak "cannon fodder" monsters that can be cunning and strong in groups, similar to goblins.

Variants

Some variants make adjustments so that female counterparts to the kobold lord are properly named and generated.

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, two kobold lords are generated alongside Kroo the Kobold King in the room-and-corridors variant of the kobold level at level creation.

GruntHack

In GruntHack, kobold lords are replaced by racial monster lords and ladies, which kobolds are eligible to generate as.

UnNetHack

In UnNetHack, kobold lords and other kobolds have a mutual grudge with elves.

dNetHack

In dNetHack, kobold lords are lawful, and become an invalid form for polymorph.

A kobold lord may appear as the ruler of a randomly-generated throne room - his court can contain kobold shamans, large kobolds, kobolds, lemures, and imps.

xNetHack

In xNetHack, the monster is known as a kobold leader, with females referred to as kobold ladies.

EvilHack

In EvilHack, the monster is referred to as a kobold noble, with females referred to as kobold ladies.

Hack'EM

In Hack'EM, the monster is also known as a kobold noble as in EvilHack.

Encyclopedia entry

The race of kobolds are reputed to be an artificial creation
of a master wizard (demi-god?). They are about 3' tall with
a vaguely dog-like face. They bear a violent dislike of the
Elven race, and will go out of their way to cause trouble
for Elves at any time.


References

  1. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 456

A '''kobold lord''', {{monsym|kobold lord}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. It has the strongest weapon attack among [[Kobold (monster class)|kobolds]], and possesses [[poison resistance]].

A kobold lord [[corpse]] is [[poison]]ous to eat.

{{upcoming|3.7.0|Kobold lords are now known as '''kobold leaders''', with "lord" and "lady" being gendered titles.}}

==Generation==
Randomly-generated kobold lords are always hostile. A [[large kobold]] can [[grow up]] into a kobold lord.

Kobold lords may appear among the hostile kobolds that generate in [[throne room]]s, as well as the various monsters that can be randomly generated by [[looting]] a throne while [[confused]] and carrying gold (provided there is no [[chest]] on the level).

A kobold lord has a {{frac|4}} chance of [[Monster starting inventory|generating with]] a stack of [[dart]]s.{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|456|nethack=3.6.7}}

==Strategy==
Though they are the strongest type of kobold a character will encounter, kobold lords are still not especially strong overall, but the strength of their weapon attack's dice means that they can pose trouble for careless early game characters with their darts or a found weapon, especially ones that have not yet found a viable set of armor.

==History==
The kobold lord first appears in [[NetHack 3.0.0]].

==Origin==
{{Wikipedia|Kobold (Dungeons & Dragons)}}
Kobolds are creatures that appear in many fantasy-themed works and media, which often borrow significantly from Germanic folklore - Germanic kobolds are a form of sprite that are generally benevolent if treated with kindness, but will respond to disrespect with anything ranging from pranks to even outright attacking and killing offenders.

''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'' in particular - and by extension, ''NetHack'' and many of its variants - depicts the kobold as a race of small reptilian humanoids with long tails, distantly related to dragons; earlier editions gave kobolds more dog-like features, which lead to many depictions of kobolds in Japanese media leaning harder in that direction after the popularity of the anime franchise ''Record of Lodoss War''. Fantasy kobolds are often considered weak "cannon fodder" monsters that can be cunning and strong in groups, similar to goblins.

==Variants==
Some variants make adjustments so that female counterparts to the kobold lord are properly named and generated.

===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], two kobold lords are generated alongside [[Kroo the Kobold King]] in the room-and-corridors variant of the [[kobold level]] at level creation.

===GruntHack===
In [[GruntHack]], kobold lords are replaced by [[racial monster]] [[Lord (GruntHack)|lords and ladies]], which kobolds are eligible to generate as.

===UnNetHack===
In [[UnNetHack]], kobold lords and other kobolds have a mutual [[grudge]] with [[Elf (monster attribute)|elves]].

===dNetHack===
In [[dNetHack]], kobold lords are lawful, and become an invalid form for [[polymorph]].

A kobold lord may appear as the ruler of a randomly-generated [[Throne room#dNetHack|throne room]] - his court can contain [[kobold shaman]]s, [[large kobold]]s, [[kobold]]s, [[lemures]], and [[imp]]s.

===xNetHack===
In [[xNetHack]], the monster is known as a '''kobold leader''', with females referred to as kobold ladies.

===EvilHack===
In [[EvilHack]], the monster is referred to as a '''kobold noble''', with females referred to as kobold ladies.

===Hack'EM===
In [[Hack'EM]], the monster is also known as a kobold noble as in EvilHack.

==Encyclopedia entry==
{{encyclopedia|<poem>
The race of kobolds are reputed to be an artificial creation
of a master wizard (demi-god?).  They are about 3' tall with
a vaguely dog-like face.  They bear a violent dislike of the
Elven race, and will go out of their way to cause trouble
for Elves at any time.
</poem>}}
